text: this is Thomas fuller in Bangkok at the
Thai capital's largest weekend market
you can find just about anything from
household goods to house pets but behind
these signs live endangered species like
Madagascar turtles and marmoset monkeys
from South America some are sold using a
loophole in Thai law that bans importing
the animals but allow selling them once
they're in the country Thailand has
stepped up its efforts against wildlife
trafficking in recent years last year
Thai authorities seized more than 16,000
animals the arrests are a good thing it
prevents illegal tiger trafficking but
at the same time it means that we have
to take care of all these Tigers they
are supposed to be in the wild but they
end up in cages here in robbery in
central Thailand the government has one
of two dozen wildlife centers bursting
with the wide assortment of exotic
wildlife rescued from smugglers whom is
a three year old tiger raised by
caretakers named after Thailand's main
international airports awana poon he was
discovered in 2010 drugged and crammed
in this suitcase the passenger was
heading to Iran the number of
confiscated Tigers continues to rise as
Thailand one of the world's biggest hubs
for illegal wildlife trafficking cracks
down Rothbury houses 72 other Tigers
including five cubs seized in October
their plans to add 20 more cages the
center is also home to Turtles and
orangutans who are particularly
mischievous several have escaped but
they never go too far
they know where dinner is served
at the Port of Bangkok officials check
for shipments of animal related products
it's one of whom Airport customs
officers have seized elephant tusks from
Africa and leopards on the way to
customers in the Middle East
birds are commonly trafficked animals
that can't be easily released into the
wild like bears and tigers are kept at
the government wildlife centers they'll
spend the rest of their lives here which
can be decades animal activists say for
too few traffickers have been arrested I
think you'll find these wildlife
confiscation centers being less crowded
and less busy as they are right now if
more money is put into wildlife law
enforcement to go after the kingpins who
are running this place for now and for
years to come the caretakers at
Thailand's government wildlife centers
have their work cut out for them
